title.narrative: Assessment study Dutch start-ups for pilot StartUpLink

description.narrative: The results of the consultant’s assessment study will be the first go/no-go moment for the implementation of a StartUpLink pilot. The need for this assessment is as follows:1. To analyze the gap that exists between existing trade mechanisms on how Dutch start-ups who wish to internationalize to Cape Town / Bangalore can be assisted in expanding towards these less well-known markets with high potential. The StartUpLink could prove to be a valuable low-cost first step that adds to the current diplomatic mechanisms used by our economic missions. The StartUpLink aims to connect Dutch start-ups to existing economic ecosystems in Cape Town and Bangalore, provide relevant and tailor-made country and sector specific information and facilitate the step for Dutch social entrepreneurs to invest in new markets that generate new business.2. StartUpLink will improve the business climate for Dutch start-ups that are looking to enter the less well-known markets of Cape Town and Bangalore, as there will be less obstacles for them to expand to these emerging markets. Furthermore, StartUpLink will likely lead to more RVO projects with better results through e.g. the Dutch Good Growth Fund, which focus is on the StartUpLink’s potential beneficiaries and DGGF’s prioritized markets (of which India and South Africa are a part of). Moreover, a StartUpLink pilot can facilitate Dutch private sector access to relevant business contacts abroad in India and South Africa. Facilitating investment in these upcoming markets, which enhances investment and trade between the private sector/start-ups of the Netherlands and India/South Africa.3. Potentially, in a later stage, when this one way street towards Cape Town and Bangalore has proven to be successful (which will be decided upon in close cooperation with RVO and BZ) the virtual network could also develop a way to attract foreign start-ups and scale-ups who are looking to enter the European market through the Netherlands. Making it a two-way street.
